edu.cmu.sphinx.linguist.dictionary

Class FullDictionary

  • java.lang.Object
    • edu.cmu.sphinx.linguist.dictionary.FullDictionary
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Dictionary, Configurable
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    TrainerDictionary

    public class FullDictionary
extends Object
implements Dictionary
    Creates a dictionary by reading in an ASCII-based Sphinx-3 format dictionary. Each line of the dictionary specifies the word, followed by spaces or tab, followed by the pronunciation (by way of the list of phones) of the word. Each word can have more than one pronunciations. For example, a digits dictionary will look like: 

     ONE                  HH W AH N
 ONE(2)               W AH N
 TWO                  T UW
 THREE                TH R IY
 FOUR                 F AO R
 FIVE                 F AY V
 SIX                  S IH K S
 SEVEN                S EH V AH N
 EIGHT                EY T
 NINE                 N AY N
 ZERO                 Z IH R OW
 ZERO(2)              Z IY R OW
 OH                   OW

    In the above example, the words "one" and "zero" have two pronunciations each.

    This dictionary will read in all the words and its pronunciation(s) at startup. Therefore, if the dictionary is big, it will take longer to load and will consume more memory.

      • loadDictionary

        protected Map<String,Word> loadDictionary(InputStream inputStream,
                                          boolean isFillerDict)
                                   throws IOException
        Loads the given sphinx3 style simple dictionary from the given InputStream. The InputStream is assumed to contain ASCII data.
        Parameters:
        inputStream - the InputStream of the dictionary
        isFillerDict - true if this is a filler dictionary, false otherwise
        Throws:
        IOException - if there is an error reading the dictionary

      • removeParensFromWord

        protected String removeParensFromWord(String word)
        Returns a new string that is the given word but with the ending parenthesis removed.

        Example: 

          "LEAD(2)" returns "LEAD"
  "LEAD" returns "LEAD"
  the word to be stripped
        Returns:
        the given word but with all characters from the first open parentheses removed
